content:
Yes, there are many Minor League Baseball players who have come from underserved communities and have later used their platform to give back to those communities. Here are a few more examples:

1. Jackie Robinson: Robinson broke the color barrier in Major League Baseball when he joined the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. He grew up in poverty in Pasadena, California, and was a vocal advocate for civil rights throughout his life. Robinson founded the Jackie Robinson Foundation, which provides scholarships and other support to minority youth.

2. Curtis Pride: Pride was born deaf and grew up in the inner city of Washington, D.C. He was drafted by the New York Mets in 1986 and played in the major leagues for several teams. After retiring, Pride founded the Together With Pride Foundation, which supports programs for the deaf and hard-of-hearing community.

3. Joe Panik: Panik grew up in Hopewell Junction, New York, and played for the San Francisco Giants in the major leagues. He has been active in several philanthropic efforts, including the Joe Panik Scholarship, which supports students at his high school alma mater.

4. Andrew McCutchen: McCutchen grew up in Fort Meade, Florida, and played for several teams in the major leagues. He has been active in several charitable organizations, including the Cutch's Crew Foundation, which he started to support youth in underserved communities.

These are just a few more examples of Minor League Baseball players who have come from underserved communities and have later used their platform to give back to those communities.
